results.headline: Review: In ‘Ice Age: Collision Course,’ a Squirrel Reorders the Universe
results.summary_short: The fifth movie in the “Ice Age” franchise includes endless wisecracks and family-values twaddle, but the 3-D animation packs some punch.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ice Age: Collision Course

results.headline: Review: ‘Absolutely Fabulous’ Brings Its Snickers and Bubbly to the Big Screen
results.summary_short: Jennifer Saunders and Joanna Lumley are back as Eddy and Patsy in this happily self-conscious feature-length goof, a film iteration of the BBC TV series.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Absolutely Fabulous: The Movie

results.headline: Review: ‘For the Plasma’ Sees the Forests for the Financials
results.summary_short: A woman combines surveillance camera images and the business pages to predict shifts in the global markets.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For the Plasma

results.headline: Review: ‘Star Trek Beyond’ Sticks to Its Brand. That’s Not Necessarily Bad.
results.summary_short: This film follows its immediate predecessors, “Star Trek” and “Into Darkness,” in sacrificing some of the old spirit to blockbuster imperatives.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Star Trek Beyond

results.headline: Review: ‘Equals,’ a Futuristic Tale of Defying Deadly Conformity
results.summary_short: Kristen Stewart and Nicholas Hoult star as workers in a dystopian commune who break the rules by experiencing feelings for each other.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Equals

results.headline: Review: A Sport Comes a Long Way in ‘Free to Run’
results.summary_short: This documentary recounts the extraordinary growth of running, from exclusive clubs to a social revolution on the streets.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free to Run

results.headline: Review: A Search for Meaning in ‘Garnet’s Gold’
results.summary_short: This documentary by Ed Perkins chronicles a search for a stash of gold, but also ends up telling a larger story about one man’s life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Garnet’s Gold

results.headline: Review: In ‘How He Fell in Love,’ an Extramarital Bond Unfolds
results.summary_short: This Marc Meyers film focuses on how the relationship between a young musician and a middle-age woman affects them and others in their orbit.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How He Fell in Love

results.headline: Review: ‘Outlaws and Angels,’ a Cross Between Western and Home-Invasion Horror
results.summary_short: Starring Chad Michael Murray and Clint Eastwood’s daughter Francesca, JT Mollner’s film features outlaws who descend on a seemingly innocent frontier family’s home.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Outlaws and Angels

results.headline: Review: ‘Lucha Mexico’ Offers a Repetitive Look at Pro Wrestlers
results.summary_short: This documentary, from Alex Hammond and Ian Markiewicz, introduces the stars of “lucha libre,” the Mexican form of the sport.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lucha Mexico

results.headline: Review: In ‘Phantom Boy,’ an Ailing Hero Takes On a Villain
results.summary_short: This animated film by Alain Gagnol and Jean-Loup Felicioli (“A Cat in Paris”) tells the story of a boy whose illness has given him a gift.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Phantom Boy

results.headline: Review: ‘Café Society’ Isn’t Woody Allen’s Worst Movie
results.summary_short: This ambivalent return to 1930s Hollywood mostly rearranges the director’s old themes. But, overall, it’s an amusing little picture.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Café Society

results.headline: Review: ‘Don’t Blink — Robert Frank,’ a Portrait of a Quintessential New York Artist
results.summary_short: Laura Israel’s documentary is less like a full-scale biography than like a magazine profile of Mr. Frank’s long and prodigious career.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Don’t Blink — Robert Frank

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Infiltrator,’ Bryan Cranston Tunnels Into a Menacing Drug Network
results.summary_short: Based on a memoir, the film depicts a federal agent who poses as a money launderer to combat Pablo Escobar’s cocaine cartel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Infiltrator

results.display_title: Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru
results.headline: Review: ‘Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru’ Depicts a Self-Help Prophet
results.summary_short: This documentary, an immersive look at one of Mr. Robbins’s Date With Destiny mega-seminars, could pass for a promotional video.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru

results.headline: Our ‘Ghostbusters’ Review: Girls Rule. Women Are Funny. Get Over It.
results.summary_short: This redo lets women, especially Kate McKinnon, be as simply and uncomplicatedly funny as men, and still leaves room for Chris Hemsworth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghostbusters

results.headline: Review: Viggo Mortensen Captivates in ‘Captain Fantastic’
results.summary_short: Mr. Mortensen is just one of the reasons to see this film about a family forced to leave their home in the woods and become reacquainted with society.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captain Fantastic

results.headline: Review: ‘Zero Days’ Examines Cyberwarfare’s Potential Online Apocalypse
results.summary_short: This Alex Gibney documentary describes the origin of Stuxnet, malware devised by Israel and the United States with grave implications for the future.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zero Days

results.headline: Review: ‘Our Little Sister,’ or What We Found at Dad’s Funeral
results.summary_short: With brilliant narrative stealth, Hirokazu Kore-eda’s film watches as three single women welcome their long-lost teenage half sister into their lives.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Our Little Sister

results.headline: Review: Fraternal Dysfunction in the Old South in ‘Men Go to Battle’
results.summary_short: This film, which takes place during the early years of the Civil War, pushes back against the rigid formality of the period genre.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Men Go to Battle
